newsitem.title: DENMARK: 24 neo-Nazis, opponents held in Denmark.
newsitem.headline: 24 neo-Nazis, opponents held in Denmark.

text.p: Twenty-four neo-Nazis and anti-Nazi anarchists were arrested in Denmark on Saturday as they headed towards this small town on the 10th anniversary of the death of Hitler's deputy, Rudolf Hess.

Police spokeswoman Benta Sessa told a news conference those arrested in Copenhagen and Roskilde were 11 neo-Nazis carrying knives, petrol bombs or other illegal weapons on their way to a Hess memorial march, 12 anarchists planning protests against the march and one other person.
About 170 neo-Nazis, many of them wearing hoods, had boarded a train headed for Roskilde, a quiet cathedral town west of Copenhagen where the march was planned.
Two of the arrested neo-Nazis were Norwegians and three German neo-Nazis had been turned back at the German border, Sessa said.

Liberal freedom of speech laws have made Denmark something of a neo-Nazi haven, to the irritation of neighbouring Germany, where Nazi tracts and symbols are banned, and to the discomfort of Danes who remember wartime Nazi occupation.
German police are also bracing for clashes with neo-Nazi groups throughout the weekend of the Hess anniversary.
A force of 800 officers has streamed into Roskilde to keep the two sides apart. Police carrying tear gas guarded all entries to the town, scrutinising vehicles and checking their occupants.
A 1995 march in the town turned into a violent rout when neo-Nazis were scattered by a far larger group of leftists.
The heaviest concentration of police was around the central railway station where officers told Reuters they feared rival groups arriving by train might clash.
